entry.title: Happy 2020 Everyone!
entry.content: Looking forward to another great year of research in the laboratory!
entry.summary: Looking forward to another great year of research in the laboratory!

entry.title: QTL mapping of neutrophil variation in stickleback

link.title: QTL mapping of neutrophil variation in stickleback

entry.content: The latest publication from the lab - genetic mapping of neutrophil variation between oceanic and freshwater stickleback.
entry.summary: The latest publication from the lab - genetic mapping of neutrophil variation between oceanic and freshwater stickleback.

entry.title: Highly Reproducible 16s Sequencing Facilitates Measurement of Host Genetic Influences on the Stickleback Gut Microbiome

link.title: Highly Reproducible 16s Sequencing Facilitates Measurement of Host Genetic Influences on the Stickleback Gut Microbiome

entry.content: Our study design and insights should provide a useful example for others desiring to quantify microbiome variation at biological levels in the face of various technical factors in a variety of systems.
entry.summary: Our study design and insights should provide a useful example for others desiring to quantify microbiome variation at biological levels in the face of various technical factors in a variety of systems.

entry.title: SCORE students in the lab
entry.content: Jade and Nia (second and third from left) and their cohort of great SCORE students working in our labs at UO this year.

entry.title: Repeated Selection of Alternatively Adapted Haplotypes Creates Sweeping Genomic Remodeling in Stickleback

link.title: Repeated Selection of Alternatively Adapted Haplotypes Creates Sweeping Genomic Remodeling in Stickleback

entry.content: A recent publication from our group identifying the distribution of haplotypes in freshwater and oceanic stickleback from recently uplifted volanic islands in Alaska.
entry.summary: A recent publication from our group identifying the distribution of haplotypes in freshwater and oceanic stickleback from recently uplifted volanic islands in Alaska.

entry.title: Ancient genomic variation underlies repeated ecological adaptation in young stickleback populations

link.title: Ancient genomic variation underlies repeated ecological adaptation in young stickleback populations

entry.content: The genomic variation that is involved in recent and rapid local adaptation in stickleback has therefore been evolving throughout the 15‐million‐year history since the two species lineages split. This long history of genomic divergence has maintained large genomic regions of ancient ancestry that include multiple chromosomal inversions and extensive linked variation.
entry.summary: The genomic variation that is involved in recent and rapid local adaptation in stickleback has therefore been evolving throughout the 15‐million‐year history since the two species lineages split. This long history of genomic divergence has maintained large genomic regions of ancient ancestry that include multiple chromosomal inversions and extensive linked variation.
